field_edited_text.value:
Policy:

The City, State, railroads and coal
companies must work to reduce any
conflicts between local traffic and
coal trains caused by increased coal
traffic.

i



2) Canton — The construction of the Can-
ton/Seagirt Marine Terminal in the late
1980’s, completion of Fort Holabird
Industrial Park and Foreign Trade Zone
and the anticipated expansion of other
industries will likely tax Broening
Highway, local streets and connectors
into 1-95 during peak hours. This may
require improvements at several loca-
tions to meet peak demand.

Perhaps the most complex transporta-
tion issues will be generated by the
increased rail traffic from coal export at®
several major grade crossings. Not only will
auto and truck traffic serving businesses be
delayed but in several locations emergency
services, such as fire engines, ambulances
and police, could be temporarily cut off
from several areas. There are also locations
in the City that may benefit from grade
separations or improved traffic control
techniques. The planned grade separation at
Boston Street in Canton will cost approxi-
mately $15 million. A full program involving
grade separations at a number of locations,
as well as signal improvements, improve-
ments to crossing surfaces, and other
related up gradings could cost up to $50
million for the port area.

An equitable formula for sharing the costs
of grade separations and other major
iImprovements required as a result of
increased coal shipment must be developed
between the City, State, railroads and coal
companies.

At-grade rail crossing blocking traffic



%
|
